items.title: 'Adult’ pressures hit hard as UNICEF warns teens are losing hope
items.summary: A new report from UNICEF Australia has found less than a third of Australian teens are feeling excited or hopeful about their futures. Mental health issues and anxiety around 'adult' challenges like housing and money are key drivers of declining wellbeing. For marginalised children and teens, these kind of pressures are felt even more acutely.

items.title: Teen charged with murder after stabbing near Sydney school
items.summary: Police said those involved were not from the nearby school and officers believe it was not a random attack.

items.summary: James Comey was charged in September with making false statements to Congress.

items.title: Bureau of Meteorology weathers website storm
items.summary: The Bureau of Meteorology's controversial website redesign carries a staggering 96 million dollar price tag. The cost blowout has drawn sharp criticism from both government ministers and the opposition. Federal Environment Minister Murray Watt has expressed deep concern over the massive expenditure, while Nationals Leader David Littleproud warns the public that the exorbitant cost will further erode trust in the agency.

items.title: COP30 deal keeps humanity 'in the fight for a liveable planet': UN chief
items.summary: Delegates to the COP30 summit in Brazil have reached an agreement to address still rising global emissions. The deal increases money to countries hit by climate change, but contains no explicit fossil fuel plan. The agreement has mollified some - and horrified others.

items.summary: With the renewable energy transition underway in Australia, the higher than expected uptake of solar panels has human rights groups concerned about links to Uyghur forced labour in the supply chain. As Australia looks into developing its own solar panel industry, rights groups say government and industry should work to ensure the clean energy transition isn't at the cost of freedom.

items.title: New names added to migration Welcome Wall at National Maritime Museum

items.title: INTERVIEW: Associate Professor Bassina Farbenblum
items.summary: As thousands of international students prepare to take summer holiday jobs, Associate Professor Bassina Farbenblum, an expert on migrants' rights from the University of New South Wales, warns that more is needed to protect students from wage theft and abuse. She says Australia has a ‘pervasive problem’ with workplace exploitation of international students and those on temporary visas. Dr Farbenblum is speaking to SBS’s Sandra Fulloon.

items.title: Underground struggles: Illegal miners risk death in Morocco's forgotten coal town
items.summary: In one of Morocco's impoverished coal towns, illegal miners continue to risk their lives to make ends meet. In an exclusive sit-down interview with SBS News, a photojournalist has shared the harsh realities he witnessed of the miners in Jerada. Ahead of the International Mining Congress in Morocco, experts are calling for better health and safety regulations to be implemented in the country.

items.title: 'Isolation and shame': Australians are avoiding perinatal mental health support, new research reveals
items.summary: Around one in four Australians are failing to seek support when experiencing perinatal mental health issues. Experts say the data released by the Gidget Foundation highlights a lack of awareness around signs and symptoms, and ongoing stigma around the issue.

This year's winners range from a year-12 graduate providing financial literacy education in developing countries, to an internationally acclaimed neurosurgeon. But the spotlight on their success has also highlighted a lack of diversity in leadership positions, known as the 'Bamboo Ceiling'.

items.title: Indonesia’s drowning island takes historic climate case to court

Neither candidate scored a majority of votes in the first round, triggering a run-off election that is expected to be dominated by votes for Chile's conservative parties.

There are now school closures and remediation efforts across South Australia, the ACT, and Tasmania over concerns about the contamination. Experts suggest the potential for long-term harm depends on the specific type of asbestos found—and whether the sand is free-flowing enough to allow for inhalation.

items.title: Bangladesh's former Prime Minister is sentenced to death
items.summary: Bangladesh has entered one of its most volatile political periods in decades after former prime minister Sheikh Hasina was sentenced to death after being convicted over last year’s student-led uprising. She strongly rejects the ruling as illegitimate and politically motivated, insisting she was denied a fair trial. The verdict has heightened fears of renewed unrest, deepening political polarisation, and uncertainty over who will lead the Awami League into future elections.

items.title: INTERVIEW: SBS talks to Kaveh Madani on Tehran's water crisis
items.summary: Kaveh Madani warned Iran about water scarcity 20 years ago. He was called a "water terrorist." Now Iran is experiencing an extreme water crisis, its like not seen for more than six decades. Tehran, famous for its surrounding snowy mountains, has had no rain in over 200 days. Its main water sources are in a dire situation; two major dams supplying the capital are at less than 10 per cent capacity. Kaveh Madani is the director of the United Nations University Institute for Water, Environment and Health, and warned of this situation back in the early 2000s, and he's speaking here to SBS broadcaster Niv Sadrolodabaee.

The Labour government has been hardening its immigration policies as it seeks to stem the surging popularity of the populist Reform UK party, which has driven the immigration agenda and forced Labour to adopt a tougher line.

items.summary: Failing to achieve net zero would "disproportionately" exacerbate the climate impacts projected for Australia, experts say. Here's how.

items.title: Three day US government shutdown ends, but investors still nervous
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with George Boubouras from K2 Asset Management Ltd about the day's market moves including how the US government shutdown will impact the US Federal Reserve's next interest rate decision, plus a preview of Nvidia's quarterly results.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 17 November 2025
items.summary: A five minute bullet in for English language learners

items.title: As the play sand asbestos scare continues to grow, here's what we know so far
items.summary: More recalls, more Canberra school closures, and the sand has been found at over 100 sites in South Australia.

items.title: Netanyahu voices opposition to Palestinian state ahead of UN Security Council vote on Gaza
items.summary: The draft resolution would follow the US-brokered ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas and mentions a possible future Palestinian state.

items.title: Coalition cements climate policy: no net zero, more fossil fuel as a move towards nuclear
items.summary: The Coalition has formally solidified its dumping of the net zero emissions target in a party room meeting in Canberra. But it's gone much further, with the Liberals and Nationals unveiling a plan to strip climate change from the national energy regulator's list of objectives, while vowing to continue to reduce emissions by monitoring the progress of other countries.

items.title: Murder of anti-drug mayor sparks Gen Z protests in Mexico
items.summary: More than 100 people were injured in the protests, which were sparked by the assassination of the mayor of the western city of Uruapan.

items.title: Australia downplays co-hosting COP31 after Türkiye proposes sharing event
items.summary: Australia and Türkiye both submitted bids in 2022 to host COP31, and neither has withdrawn, leading to an attention-sapping impasse.

items.title: I was abandoned as a baby. I want to ask my mother why
items.summary: As a newborn, Caron Michelle Brown was left on the steps of a health clinic. She's still searching for her mother — and her own identity.

items.title: Need a new job? These are the top 10 skills Australian employers are looking for
items.summary: Despite concerns about AI and job losses, there is enduring demand for uniquely human skills, new analysis suggests.

items.title: "Australia have got this": Socceroos remember World Cup qualifier against Uruguay, 20 years on
items.summary: In 2005, the Socceroos defeated Uruguay in Sydney, qualifying for the FIFA World Cup for the first time in 32 years. Twenty years later, two of the men that played a key role in securing the victory have reunited to recount the night few will ever forget.

items.title: Opposition presents its plan to put power prices at the centre of climate and energy policy
items.summary: After a period of internal dispute over emissions reduction targets, the Coalition has presented a climate and energy plan.

items.title: UK Labour strips asylum seeker rights amid surging support for Nigel Farage's Reform party
items.summary: Among other changes, the duty to provide support to certain asylum seekers, including housing and weekly allowances, will be revoked.

items.title: Thousands march in Brazil in first big UN climate protest in years
items.summary: It was the first major protest outside the annual climate talks since COP26 four years ago in Glasgow.

items.title: Palestinians who 'mysteriously' landed in South Africa had third-country approval, Israel says
items.summary: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa said it seemed like the Gazans "were being flushed out".

items.title: INTERVIEW: The Great Koala Count and the citizen scientists involved
items.summary: Scientists in South Australia are asking the public to help count koalas - in a citizen science initiative that could have national implications.

items.title: INTERVIEW: The Great Koala Count and the citizen scientists involved
items.summary: Scientists in South Australia are asking the public to help count koalas - in a citizen science initiative that could have national implications.

items.title: INTERVIEW: NITV Radio talks to Dr Harry Hobbs on Victoria's treaty becoming law
items.summary: This week a treaty between Victoria and the state's First Nations people became law. Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan, First Peoples' Assembly of Victoria co-chairs Ngarra Murray and Rueben Berg signed the treaty at a formal ceremony at Government House on Thursday morning. Kerri-Lee Barry from SBS' NITV Radio has spoken with UNSW Law & Justice Associate Professor, Dr Harry Hobbs, about the historic agreement.

items.title: 'The worst possible situation': This major city only has a few days of water left
items.summary: Tehran's main water sources are in a dire situation, with two major dams reaching what officials are calling "dead capacity".

items.title: New health advice issued after asbestos found in kids' play sand sold at major retailers
items.summary: Regulators say the health risk is low but recommend careful disposal methods as the investigation into contaminated play sand continues.

items.title: Worth up to $100k and hidden in chocolate boxes: Inside Australia's illegal animal trade
items.summary: Global illegal trade in wildlife is estimated to be worth $32 billion, with rare species in Australia at risk.

items.title: Australia welcomes Trump's backtrack on food-import tariffs
items.summary: The new exemptions mark a sharp reversal for US President Donald Trump, who has long insisted that his import duties are not fuelling inflation.

items.title: As power prices surge, David has found ways to cut running costs by thousands
items.summary: Rising electricity prices are a major driver of headline inflation, putting pressure on households and Australia’s 2.6 million small business owners. Some are beating the odds – here’s how.

items.title: April Le Sueur claims 2025 NATSI Sports Award
items.summary: A young volunteer for a football club in central Victoria has won the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander (NATSI) Sports Awards this year. April Le Sueur has been volunteering at the Rumbalara Football and Netball Club in the Victorian town of Shepparton. She's also the AFL Young Leader of the Year.

items.title: How David's 'game-changing' system saves him up to $50,000 a year
items.summary: Small business owner David Stuart was spending about $24,000 a year on electricity — until a solar overhaul changed everything.

items.title: This film starring Rose Byrne airs the unspeakable parts of motherhood
items.summary: Motherhood is often seen as an idealised, glossy experience. But this new film from Rose Byrne aims to unpack the stigma that comes with regretting having children.

items.title: 20,000 new Epstein documents just dropped. Here's what we learned
items.summary: The White House criticised the Democrats' smaller document release, saying it was selectively chosen to make Trump look bad.

items.title: Dementia now Australia's biggest killer, as leading causes of death revealed
items.summary: Dementia deaths have risen steadily over the past decade, reflecting Australia's ageing population, according to the ABS.

items.title: What does the treaty with Indonesia actually mean?
items.summary: Australia's leaders remain circumspect about the terms of a security agreement with a key northern neighbour after finalising the deal with Indonesia's president. But Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the deal commits the nations to consult regularly on matters of security, and consider possible measures should either's security be threatened.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 14 November 2025
items.summary: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

items.title: ‘Popping champagne corks’: Climate change boss lashes Coalition for dumping net zero
items.summary: Matt Kean said his former party is walking away from scientific evidence — and pandering to mining lobbyists.

items.title: Hopes dashed as global fossil fuel emissions increase in 2025
items.summary: For the second straight year, emissions from fossil fuels rose by slightly more than one per cent. Scientists at the COP30 climate conference in Brazil say it's one of the smallest in recent non-pandemic years - but it means efforts to curb warming global temperatures by getting fossil fuel emissions to stop rising are still not meeting targets.

items.title: Settler attack on a mosque sparks international condemnation
items.summary: A fresh settler attack on a mosque in the occupied West Bank has drawn sharp international condemnation and intensified scrutiny of Israel’s handling of rising violence in the territory. The arson and vandalism at Deir Istiya, which left Korans burned and hate-filled graffiti on the walls, comes amid warnings from the United Nations that such assaults risk fuelling a wider regional crisis.

items.title: The mystery of Australia's deepest lake has finally been solved
items.summary: A CSIRO team spent nine days on Tasmania's Lake St Clair, and they've finally answered one key question: how deep it really is.

items.title: Having 'a crack': What's the go with the social media ban?
items.summary: Weeks out from Australia's world-first age restrictions being implemented, there are still plenty of questions about the platforms that will fall under the ban, the ones that won't and how companies are actually going to figure out users' ages at all. This week, Elfy and Rania chat about what we know so far and how it's all reflecting on the Albanese government right now.

items.title: Israel identifies deceased hostage returned by Hamas
items.summary: Israeli authorities say the bodies of three hostages are still being held in the Gaza Strip.

items.title: How this rising star responded to men telling her she was 'too pretty to do comedy'
items.summary: Elouise Eftos is used to people judging her on her appearance. With her hit debut comedy show, she's having the last laugh.

items.title: Australia's 'flawed' health star ratings face criticism as they hit a deadline
items.summary: A deadline for Australia's contentious Health Star Rating system has arrived — and could spark big change.

items.title: Historic Victorian treaty the start of a new era, Indigenous leaders say
items.summary: It's been hailed as a moment centuries in the making: the signing of Australia's first ever state-wide treaty with Aboriginal people, described as something once thought impossible. The Australian-first treaty will take effect just before Christmas but will not be up and running until mid-2026. And for both sides signing the pact in Victoria, there's recognition of more hard work that needs to be done.

items.title: 'Cigars and champagne': The Netanyahu corruption case at the centre of Trump's pardon plea
items.summary: The Israeli prime minister has faced a years-long trial over allegations of fraud and accepting bribes.

items.title: CEO Series: Xero's Sukhinder Singh Cassidy & ASX tumbles on jobs gain
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Xero CEO Sukhinder Singh Cassidy following the accounting software group's 42% rise in half-year profit to find out where growth is coming from and how it is using AI; Devika Shivadekar from RSM Australia goes through the better-than expected labour force report to explain what it means for interest rates; plus the market reaction with Zoran Kresovic from Blueberry Markets.

items.title: Philippines in tatters, Trump taps a former terrorist and, well, Bob Ross
items.summary: Typhoon Fung Wong leaves a vast trail of destruction in the Philippines, Syrian President Al-Sharaa shoots hoops before meeting Trump and Trump COPs it in Brazil. Also Zelenskyy under fire from corruption allegations, why AI is spreading Russian propaganda, and Bob Ross makes a splash.

items.title: What is next for the Liberals now they have scrapped their net zero commitment?
items.summary: The Liberal Party has voted to officially abandon its net zero by 2050 emissions reduction target, following a contentious internal meeting. This dramatic policy reversal, which will also seek to remove the target from the Climate Change Act, has triggered fierce internal debate among senior members and drawn criticism from the government and independents.

items.title: The Liberal Party has dumped net zero — but the Coalition's real battle lies ahead
items.summary: Sussan Ley has held her ground as the Liberals drop their net zero pledge. But unity, and credibility on climate, remain up for grabs.

items.title: Ukraine's Zelenskyy orders ministers to quit over $100 million energy scandal
items.summary: Ukraine's President, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, has called for the removal of the nation's justice and energy ministers, amid a wide-reaching corruption scandal involving the state nuclear power company. One minister has submitted her resignation, the other has been suspended. Ukraine’s anti-corruption agency has carried out a major investigation, involving alleged kickbacks worth around $100 million in the energy sector.

items.title: 'Side by side': Australia's first treaty with Aboriginal people signed into law in Victoria
items.summary: Before today, Australia was one of few Commonwealth countries without any treaties in place with its First Nations peoples.

items.title: The record-breaking US shutdown has finally ended, as bill heads to Trump's desk
items.summary: The House passed a spending bill that will end the longest government shutdown in US history.

items.title: The record-breaking US shutdown has finally ended, as bill heads to Trump's desk
items.summary: The House passed a spending bill that will end the longest government shutdown in US history.

items.title: 'Demands urgent attention': Study finds widening disparities in cancer survival rates
items.summary: The equity gap has swelled since four decades ago, according to analysis of data from almost one million cancer patients.

items.title: Why young, child-free men like Trent are choosing permanent contraception
items.summary: Trent is among the men choosing a vasectomy, challenging ideas around contraception and rethinking having kids in a world of rising costs.

items.title: Property investor loans at record & market sentiment bullish despite down day
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Maree Kilroy from Oxford Economics Australia about the latest home loan data which shows lending to investors hit a record high to find out what it means for supply; plus James Gerrish from Market Parters takes a look at the day's market action and reveals what he's telling his clients.

items.title: 'Punishing trauma': Experts say proposal to fix 'crime capital' could have opposite effect
items.summary: Young offenders in Victoria could face life imprisonment under proposed reforms, but advocates say the move won't make communities safer.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 12 November 2025
items.summary: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

items.title: At COP30, Indigenous leaders demand greater powers to protect their land.
items.summary: Indigenous leaders in the Amazon are urging leaders at the UN Climate Summit to empower First Nations people to protect their land and rainforests. As world leaders gather in the Amazonian city of Belem, pressure is on to go beyond words and ideas and start implementing meaningful policy.

items.title: Victoria to introduce 'adult time for violent crime' reform in response to rising crime
items.summary: Children as young as 14 could face possible life sentences under the proposed changes to be announced by the Victorian premier on Wednesday.

items.title: Australia's dispute with Türkiye over COP31 hosting rights could see both miss out
items.summary: Ethiopia will host the UN's COP32 climate summit in 2027, but next year's COP31 remains a contest between Türkiye and Australia.

items.title: 'God's not making any more land': Price gap between homes and apartments growing
items.summary: On average, houses in capital cities are nearly 50 per cent more expensive than apartments. Five years ago, the gap was only 20 per cent.

items.title: 'State of war': Pakistan defence minister's warning after suicide bombing kills 12
items.summary: Pakistani government ministers accused neighbouring Afghanistan of complicity in the bloodshed — an accusation they denied.

items.title: Is your blocked nose a sign of hay fever or a cold? Here's what to know
items.summary: Duration and triggers for symptoms can provide clues.

items.title: The 'incredibly toxic' hidden ingredient experts want banned from our supermarkets
items.summary: Researchers analysed 28,000 products stocked in Australian supermarkets. Here's what they found.

items.title: The Dismissal: how it all played out
items.summary: On November 11, 1975, Australia experienced its most dramatic constitutional crisis when Governor-General Sir John Kerr dismissed Prime Minister Gough Whitlam 50 years ago. We examine the full story of the Dismissal, from the political deadlock and the Loans Affair to Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's recent claim of a "partisan political ambush" and new evidence suggesting foreign interference.

items.title: 'You could die, make a will': Australia's fresh warning amid 'dark' travel trend
items.summary: Australians have been kidnapped, detained and targeted by terror attacks in this central Asian country, Smartraveller warns.

items.title: Why consumers are optimistic despite inflation & CBA Q2 profit rises 2%
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Westpac's Matt Hassan about a dramatic rise in consumer confidence, despite reaccelerating inflation and diminishing prospects of lower interest rates; plus the day on the sharemarket with Jamie Hannah from VanEck, including a closer look at the Commonwealth Bank's latest profit result.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 11 November 2025
items.summary: A five minute bulletin for English Language learners

items.title: Shock resignations, $1.5bn threat: How a 12 second clip of Donald Trump could cost the BBC
items.summary: The BBC's director general and head of news have both quit over a documentary that misleadingly edited clips of US President Donald Trump.

items.title: INTERVIEW: BBC is facing an orchestrated campaign to undercut public trust says analyst
items.summary: The director for the International Centre for Journalists says the resignation of two senior figures at the BBC is a result of an "orchestrated campaign to undercut public trust" in the broadcaster. The head of the BBC, director-general Tim Davie and news CEO Deborah Turness both resigned after criticism of the broadcaster’s editing of a speech by US President Donald Trump. Critics said the way the speech was edited for the BBC's flagship documentary program Panorama last year was misleading and cut out a section where Donald Trump said that he wanted supporters to demonstrate peacefully. Mr Trump has threatened legal action against the BBC over the way the speech he made was edited. Julie Posetti is a professor of journalism at City St George's University of London and director for the International Centre for Journalists and she's speaking here to AP.

items.title: Hopes of end to US shutdown lifts markets; ANZ profit slump
items.summary: Growing optimism that the US government shutdown could end this week has lifted share markets, including the ASX-200. Plus, ANZ has reported a full-year cash profit of $5.8 billion, down by 14 per cent after factoring in legal penalties and the costs of mass redundancies. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Mathan Somasundaram, CEO of Deep Data Analytics.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 10 November 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: 'It shouldn't be painful to be a woman': Victorian report lays bare health care battle
items.summary: The Victorian government has released the final report of an inquiry into women's experiences of pain - and it's made for some uncomfortable reading. Shaped by the experiences of 13,000 women and girls, the report has revealed gender health gaps, experiences of medical bias, sexism and misogyny, and feelings of being ignored or dismissed by clinicians are rampant throughout the Victorian health system.

items.title: Israel confirms remains returned are soldier Hadar Goldin killed in Gaza in 2014
items.summary: Israeli authorities have received the remains of a hostage which Hamas says is the body of an Israeli soldier who was killed in 2014 and held for 11 years.

items.title: 'We now have a group chat': How five single mothers came together to reveal a love scam
items.summary: A group of Chinese Australian single mothers were shocked to discover they'd all dated the same man — in some cases at the same time.

items.title: One million permanent humanitarian visas: Calls for change as milestone nears
items.summary: While advocates celebrate Australia's one millionth permanent humanitarian visa, experts also say Australia needs to reassess its approach.
